title: sajid javid fresh ideas brexit defeating corbyn
story: The Pakistani immigrants’ son rose to wealth and power entirely on talent.And his humble background could not be more dferent from, say, Boris  Johnson’s. Many of his ideas chime with The Sun and our readers too.And we agree, to an extent, when he says the country needs a “new kind of leader”, one that’s “not just for Brexit”.The reality, though, is that delivering Brexit and defeating Corbyn ARE currently all that matters.If Labour’s Marxist extremists win power, via the Tories shipping votes to Nigel Farage, they will not only wreak havoc. They will skew the voting system to keep power for a decade or more.The threat is monumental.None of the leadership contenders’ backstories, grand philosophical visions or elegant speeches will matter a damnthey can’t prevent it.For all the leftie sniping, this race has revealed the makings of a highly ­talented and energetic new Cabinet under a PM capable — unlike Theresa May — of letting them off the leash.That new leader must be the one most capable of delivering on Brexit, winning back Farage voters and beating Corbyn.That’s all Tories have to decide. The rest, for now, is noise.THE time has come to stop prosecuting TV viewers for non-payment of the licence fee.This absurd tax on your telly belongs to another century. Not one in which fantastic subscription services open up a world of choice.The BBC’s callous decision to sting .million OAPs for £ a year — pleading poverty despite its £billion annual subsidy — should be the last straw.Hundreds of thousands  may forget to pay, or refuse. And it will be an outrageANY of society’s most vulnerable people are dragged to court and punished.If the Government will not scrap the licence fee entirely, the BBC must cut executive salaries and waste, reduce its services and relent over old folk.If it won’t, its power must be limited to cutting off services, like an energy firm does as a last resort, and only then the live TV or iPlayer the licence covers.Luckily there’s plenty more now to watch.We are backing Age UK’s Switched Off campaign to save free TV for older people. The charity is demanding that the Government takes back responsibility for funding free TV licences and has set up a petition on its website. Sign it on their site or on The Sun’s website.THE let-off for Oxfam beggars belief.These champions of the poor covered up the sex abuse of children by aid workers to keep donations pouring in.They tolerated “a culture of poor behaviour”, according to a damning Charity Commission report.What is their penance  A warning. No one is singled out or fired.Oxfam “reforms” and carries on. And the public is supposed to be reassured.What a whitewash.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dobby elf mystery viral cctv
story: They have come up with answers by analysing the surveillance footage which sent the internet into a spin last week.Vivian Gomez, a mother of a nine-year-old boy, was left stunned when her CCTV captured a bizarre creature - which looked like Dobby the Elf from the Harry Potter films - outside her home.Gomez uploaded the footage and said the creature was frolicking in the night and stopped at the front of the car and then did a little dance on her driveway in Colorado Springs.She shared the clip on Facebook, writing: “First I saw the shadow walking from my front door then I saw this thing....has anyone  seen this on their cameras ... The other two cameras didn’t pick it up for some reason.But self-declared experts have said they are certain the footage had not been doctored with computer trickery.And some web sleuths claimed they had the answer to the mystery.They claimed the creature was most likely a skinny child wearing flip-flops and pants on their head.In an interview with Inside Edition, Gomez admitted her son, Bobby, likes to joke around and loves to dance.When asked whether the creature could be her son, Gomez replied: No ... I wouldnt let him out at dark by himself.She also said none of the neighbourhood children looked anything like the creature.Whatever the explanation, many Potter fans were eager to celebrate a possibleof Dobby, as the beloved character tragically died in the sixth film Deathly Hallows.Maury Wills wrote on Facebook: “Dobby came to make sure you are safe!”One Twitter user then added: “Everyone’s joking that this is Dobby but I’m here deciding not to go outside at night ever again.”Eagle-eyed Twitter users pointed out that at one stage in the video there appears to be two shadows which suggests someone could be operating an elf-like puppet.Another explanation offered was that the weird figure was superimposed onto the footage using some clever camera trickery.Reactions to Dobbys death were so emotional that writer JK Rowling was moved to apologise on Twitter in  for killing off the free elf.This year, I apologise for killing someone who didnt die during the #BattleofHogwarts, but who laid down his le to save the people whod win it. I refer, of course, to Dobby the house elf, she wrote.

title: bbc tv licence elderly gary lineker resource schedulers
story: Director-General Tony Hall has decided to end free TV licences for people over the age of . If they’d made Diane Abbott the new Doctor Who they couldn’t have aroused more anger.That’s up to .million pensioners, including D-Day heroes, now forced to fork out for Auntie’s criminal tax of £..There’s already a huge petition demanding Lord Hall thinks again. And pensioner organisations are calling for a boycott of BBC programmes.Count me in. Hell, it won’t be much to give up, will it Not only that, but soon — presumably — the Beeb will be hauling -year-olds into court because they haven’t coughed up their fee.That’ll be good publicity, won’t it  And it will convince even more people that not paying the licence should be decriminalised. As it should.The BBC is insisting that this was a “tough decision to take”. And thatthey didn’t do it, they’d have to close some channels down.Really  How about sacking Gary Lineker  Does he really deserve almost million quid a year for whining about Brexit and telling you what’s coming next on Match Of The Day There are plenty more big-star salaries that could be sacriced, too.But how about getting rid of the vast swathe of middle managers in the BBC When I was a journo there I had to answer to about  bosses, most of who were inept and who usually disagreed with each other. More bosses than you could shake a stick at.There’s , people working for the BBC. If you got rid of a few thousand middle managers the output would improve and they’d have easily saved their money.Director-Generals always say they’re going to cut down on the middle managers. They never do.Director-Generals also say they’re going to spend less on consultants. Lord Hall promised precisely this. But last year they INCREASED that spending to £.million.Or how about they close down the BBC’s online service, which competes against commercial organisations and is utterly unnecessary This is the problem — well, one problem — with the Beeb. It over-reaches. It’s meant to make nice radio and TV programmes we might all enjoy. But that’s long forgotten.It now tries to do everything. And it tramples on commercial organisations which don’t have a yearly licence fee to support their grandiose schemes.Have a look at the web page for BBC jobs. They’re asking for architects, data scientists and resource schedulers.I haven’t a clue what a resource scheduler is, but I bet the BBC could get by without one. And architects This is all a real own goal by the BBC. More and more people are sick to the back teeth of its relentless political bias, its political correctness and the lack of decent stuff you might want to watch or hear.Truth is, it shouldn’t be just the pensioners who should be excused paying the licence fee.It is time it was removed from the rest of us as well.It’s long outlived its usefulness.SO, Boris has unveiled his leadership bid.Lower taxes and a definite exit from the European Union by October .I’ve always had my doubts about Boris as a Prime Minister. But then I saw how he was described in .“That incompetent, manipulative, lazy, over-entitled, media-constructed and media-protected fatberg of dishonesty.”If those bozos hate him so much, he can’t be all bad, can he WHO are you rooting for in the Conservative leadership race  The skaghead or the coke fiend Rory Stewart has admitted to smoking opium. Michael Gove has ’fessed up to taking cocaine “a number of times” back in the s.It’s only a matter of time before we discover that Andrea Leadsom likes nothing more than chasing the dragon and Jeremy Hunt spends every evening at home with his crack pipe.And God only knows what Boris is on. Horse tranquillisers chased with methamphetamine, I would guess.Although I have no evidence for any of these suggestions, of course.We gave the city back to China more than  years ago. China promised to allow the place autonomy and democracy.But China, a ruthless totalitarian state, is closing its grip on the little island.In future, people arrested in Hong Kong can be extradited to the mainland. It’s time we intervened and stood firm with the protestors for democracy.I HATE to spoil the party – but this Women’s World Cup thing, you know The women are about as good at playing football as I am at ironing.A team of men – any men – would beat every team in the competition with ease. Eventhe men had Stevie Wonder in goal, Stephen Hawking on the wing and Jacob Rees-Mogg at centre-forward.Yes, I know Stephen Hawking’s dead, but my point still stands. And it is all being rammed down our throats for political reasons. Meanwhile, out in France, they can’t sht tickets for the games. Nobody cares.Clare Balding once exhorted us all to watch women’s football because there was never any trouble on the terraces.No, indeed. There’s nobody there.YAY, welcome to the UK, Leonard-Valter Tudor – crazy name, crazy guy.The Romanian pitched up here last Friday. The following day he was arrested for trying to shoplt £ worth of stuff from TKMaxx.On Monday he was sentenced to  weeks in a young offenders’ institute.The proper ending to this story would see Lenny kicked out of the country as soon as he finishes his sentence.But nope, he intends to make a le for himself – and his we and child – in South Yorkshire. Lucky South Yorkshire.How come we are so powerless to deport costly petty criminals like Leonard It asked them to carry out a calculation involving calories. This “triggered” the little mites, apparently.They started worrying about weight loss and whether or not they were obese. One student was so upset she had to leave the exam hall “in a panic”.Do you ever worry about the sort of gener- ation we’re bringing up And what will happen to them once they get out into the real world THE latest site of choice for glamour models to pose is Chernobyl, scene of the worst nuclear disaster in history.I dunno what it’s supposed to tell us all.“This lass is so anxious to get her kit off she’s now ingested a bunch of Strontium- and is glowing like a Belisha beacon.”People do very strange things to get our attention.We are backing Age UK’s Switched Off campaign to save free TV for older people. The charity is demanding that the Government takes back responsibility for funding free TV licences and has set up a petition on its website. Sign it on their site or on The Sun’s website.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: julian assange extradition request sajid javid signed off
story: British Home Secretary Sajid Javid revealed he had signed the request yesterday - with the matter to now go before the courts tomorrow.Assange, , is facing charges of computer hacking and disclosing classied documents in what has been described as one of the largest compromises of classied information in the history of the United States.If found guilty, he faces up to  years in jail. He is currently behind bars in the UK, serving  months for breaching bail for hiding in the Ecuador embassy.Mr Javid told BBC Radio s Today programme: I am very pleased that the police were finally able to apprehend him and now hes rightly behind bars because he broke UK law.There is an extradition request from the US that is before the courts tomorrow. But yesterday I signed the extradition order and certied it and that will be going in front of the courts tomorrow.He said it was a decision for the courts over whether Assange should be extradited, adding: There is a very important part of it for the Home Secretary and I want to see justice done at all times and weve got a legitimate extradition request so Ive signed it but the final decision is now with the courts.Assange has been attempting to block extradition to the United States on charges of computer hacking and disclosing classied documents.A Home Office spokesman said: Mr Assange was arrested in relation to a provisional extradition request from the United States of America.He is accused of offences including computer misuse and the unauthorised disclosure of national defence information.We have received the full extradition request, which has been certied by the Home Secretary.This case is now before the courts and it would be inappropriate to comment further.It comes after a court ruled Julian Assange cannot be extradited to Sweden to face rape charges, which he has always denied.The ruling doesnt mean a preliminary investigation in Sweden is to be abandoned, only that -year-old Assange shouldnt be extradited and could be questioned in Britain.In April, Assange was evicted from the Ecuadorian Embassy in London where he had been holed up claiming political asylum since .Assange was then immediately arrested by British police on April  and is currently serving a -week sentence in Britain for jumping bail in .After being jailed, the WikiLeaks founder was moved to a medical ward in the high security Belmarsh prison last month and his supporters expressed grave concerns about his health.The -year-olds father John Shipton arrived at the prison with Chinese activist Ai Weiwei yesterday afternoon.

title: brexit change uk swap name yet again
story: The beleaguered Brexit-basher group said this afternoon they would now be known as The Independent Group for Change after Change.org said it would sue their MPs inidually unless they budged.It comes after a series of gaffes by the crisis-hit party, and several other name changes in their three short months of existence.The Independent Group for Change has also been known as Change UK, The Independent Group, For Change Now, Vote For Change. and TIG.In a statement released today they said: We are now legally obliged to make a formal application to the Electoral Commission, to amend our name by th June, so today we are applying to register ourselves as ‘The Independent Group for Change and will await the Electoral Commissions decision.Just weeks ago the party - which was originally made of ex-Tory and Labour MPs - split in two after the partys dire European election performance.It lost half its MPs including interim leader Heidi Allen, just  days after its launch.The group has been dogged by in-fighting and arguments over tactics since it was set up back in March, sending shockwaves through Westminster.But for weeks they were deeply ided over whether to work with the Liberal Democrats in an alliance to try and force through a second referendum.Ex-Tory MP Anna Soubry and former Labour MP Chris Leslie said they would keep fighting.Rumours have been re that some of the latest splitters could join their third party in as many months and join the Liberal Democrats.In March a group of Labour MPs left over Jeremy Corbyn and the partys failure to tackle anti-Semitism, and three Tories quit to fight for a second referendum.But the party have made a series of huge errors and ended up polling just . per cent in the European elections and not getting a single MEP elected.

title: heavily pregnant mum mouldy flat
story: Charley Lucas, from Keresley, Coventry is seven months pregnant and has lived in the mould-infested flat for three years.The social housing tenant noticed the damp in June, , but claims flat owners Whitefriars Housing still haven’t fixed the mould, which is so bad it broke the bed and makes her kids ill.Charley said: I am feeling really frustrated. It is breaking me and Im at breaking point.A couple of weeks later my bed collapsed, and that was when I realised something wasnt right.I contacted them and am having to fight them to get people out, and made repairs about a year and a half ago and re-plastered bedroom walls.”The mum-of-two added: It is on my kids clothes, they are constantly ill, and Im seven months pregnant - we shouldnt live like this.Mould also covered her walls and she had to throw out belongings ruined by the damp.Despite being seven months pregnant Charley said she was forced to scrub the walls with bleach to battle the mould.She said: I cant move as I have nowhere  to go and they have told me they are not willing to move me as they think it is still habitable.“Even though they say they have done work it just doesnt seem to have worked.I just dont know what to do anymore.Horric photos show mould covering her daughter’s bed.But owners Whitefriars Housing say staff were subjected to “extreme verbal abuse” by Ms Lucas and her partner when they visited the flat.A spokesperson for Whitefriars Housing said: “We have agreed to complete work to alleviate the issues in Ms Lucas’s home.“These are not severe and are not signicant enough to move her out of her home while the work is completed.“On a visit to Ms Lucas’s home earlier this month to establish how to approach this work members of our team were forced to leave after being subjected to extreme verbal abuse by Ms Lucas and her partner.”The housing company said they would continue to work with Ms Lucas to fix the mould.Ms Lucas denied being aggressive towards housing workers and insisted Whitefriars “failed to work with me”.She accused them of “trying to…make me look like a bad person”.Ms Lucas said: “While I agree there was confrontation between them and my partner I showed no aggression whatsoever.If Whitefriars truly believed we were both aggressive I dont understand why social services were not called in as both my children were present at that time.”

title: brit ex commando donates toes hotel cocktail
story: Brit Nick Grfiths, , had three amputated after competing in an extreme winter ultra-marathon in Canada last year.In hospital a nurse joked he should give them to a local hotel which serves a cocktail containing a human toe.Nick, who had to pull out of the Yukon Arctic Ultra amid -C temperatures, recalled: “It is a bit bizarre but I thought it’d be a laugh. You have to see the funny side of things.”The dad of two ed home to Bolton with his toes in jars, then later decided to post them in a jfy bag to the Downtown Hotel in Dawson City.After six weeks with no news, Nick feared they had been intercepted by customs. But last week he was told they had arrived at the hotel, and were being prepared for their “Sourtoe Cocktail”.They will now be mummied, which takes six weeks, and then the hotel will fly him out so he can sample one.For over four decades, tourists and residents there have been able to order a drink of their choice, such as a Yukon Jack whisky liqueur, with a human toe floating inside.Former marine Nick said: “I’m pretty confident I’ll be the first person to have had a Sourtoe Cocktail with their own toe. It’d be greatmy daughters came too. Amy is  and Hannah is  so they’re both old enough to try it.”Hotel manager Adam Gerle said of his toes: “They are very hard to come by these days and this generous ‘toe-nation’ will help ensure the tradition continues.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: matt hancock drop out tory leadership race
story: His team was locked in discussions about how to proceed after securing just  votes in yesterday’s first round of voting in the race to replace Theresa May - just three votes above the threshold to qualy for Tuesday’s second round.One MP on his campaign said: “He’s considering all his options.”Another said: “He’ll take stock and work out what to do overnight.” His campaign fear MPs could flock to rival Tory moderate Rory Stewart’s campaign after his surprise performance in the contest so far.But Mr Hancock’s campaign spokesman denied he would drop out before tomorrow’s pm deadline toofficially enter the second round of voting. He said: “He performed above expectations in the first round and is still in the race.”One MP on Team Hancock said Mr Stewart had a “messianic aura” about him at the moment.Home Secretary Sajid Javid’s campaign vowed to stay in the race despite winning just  votes.One MP on his campaign said they had received “several calls” from MPs on other campaigns who were ready to jump ship and back Mr Javid due to his pitch as the “change candidate”.The MP said: “It’s genuinely all to play for.”Some of Mr Hancock’s backers think he should pull out of the contest because they fear the moderate wing of the party is being split.They say Mr Stewart will refuse to pull out of the contest – and so Mr Hancock may bow out to make sure a moderate is on the ballot paper.One backer told The Sun: “He is thinking about the next steps very carefully.”The MP said Mr Stewart’s insurgent campaign is splitting the moderate vote.They added: “It is iding that side of the party between people who many have gone for Sajid and Matt are now split three ways.“Rory’ is definitely increasing support and it is going to make it hard for another moderate to make a final dash.”Team Hunt, Team Saj, Team Raab and Team Bojo have all been firing off texts begging Mr Hancock’s backers to switch to them.The source said: “They are all out to pick people off. I think they see Matt as the weakest.“Rory has a messianic aura about him at the moment. People are going to stick with him through thick and thin.They used specially printed ballot papers in a wood-led Commons committee room, before bosses of the powerful  Committee tallied up the votes and announced them to MPs.Three of the ten candidates were expelled from the race after failing to pass the threshold of  votes -  per cent of the party.The other seven will go through to the second ballot which opens at pm on Tuesday and closes two hours later.In that round they need to get at least  votes to stay in the contest - meaning Dominic Raab, Sajid Javid, Matt Hancock and Rory Stewart will lose unless they pick up extra support over the weekend.In the unlikely event all remaining candidates pass that figure, the contender with the fewest votes drops out.If a third ballot is required it will take place on Wednesday, with any further ballots needed coming in quick succession on Thursday.The rounds will continue until there are just two candidates left - almost certain to be Boris Johnson and one other.The final decision then passes to Tory activists who will vote by post to elect the new party leader and Prime Minister.“ I think they see Matt’s supporters as more pragmatic.”On who Mr Hancock’s supporters could switch to, they added: “I think it will be quite scattered. Probably Hunt will do best and the rest will scatter.”After the results were announced Mr Hancock tweeted: “Thanks so much for the fantastic support - terric to have more votes from colleagues than I could have hoped for #letsmoveforward.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: russian dogs first in space
story: “It’s beautul, what beauty!” he exclaimed.However, Gagarin was not the first to make the journey, nor to fly in the Soviet Union’s new Vostok space capsule.Over the previous nine months, ten dogs had also attempted it. Only six made it back alive.Most of the flights were secret and dozens of dogs lost their lives, but the knowledge gained still helps astronauts today.A few weeks before Gagarin’s flight, Nasa scientists strapped a chimp called Ham into an experimental Mercury capsule.After a -minute flight, the spacecraft splashed down and scientists opened the hatch. Ham seemed to be smiling. Primate experts later described the look on his face as one of utter terror.Dogs proved much more amenable than chimps or monkeys to being strapped into rockets.In the summer of , biologists from the Moscow Aviation Institute spent their evenings driving around looking for stray dogs.Female dogs were chosen due to their size and temperament. The dogs needed to weigh less than lb and be small enough to fit into the nose cone of a rocket.Whenever the scientists spotted a potential stray, they jumped out of their cars with sausage meat in hand.After months of selection and testing,  dogs were chosen.They were shipped out to a secret rocket test site in the desert at Kapustin Yar, near Stalingrad, now Volgograd.In the early hours of July , , the first two dogs were ready for blast-off. Tsygan, translated as Gypsy, and Dezik were loaded into a sealed compartment at the top of a cigar-shaped experimental rocket.Just before dawn, chief rocket engineer Sergei Korolev gave the order to launch.Tsygan and Dezik struggled against the pressure of acceleration. Then,  miles above the Earth — as they became the highest-ever living creatures — the dogs’ compartment separated and began to fall back to the ground.During these  seconds, the animals would have experienced weightlessness.As the dogs neared the ground, parachutes opened to slow their fall.When ground crew opened the hatch, not only were the dogs alive, they seemed to be no worse for wear from their adventure.A few days later, on July , Dezik was once again strapped into the top of a rocket for a second of these suborbital parabolic flights, accompanied by another dog, Lisa.As the dogs’ compartment plummeted, no parachute opened and the animals were killed.Tsygan was retired and lived for another ten years at the home of a space scientist.By , the Soviet space programme had relocated to a larger and more isolated site. A new rocket would achieve a speed of almost seven miles per second, enough to escape the planet’s gravity and reach orbit.On October , Korolev launched the first satellite, Sputnik .Circling the Earth every  minutes, the beeping silver sphere sent America into a frenzy.Soviet Premier Nikita Khrushchev demanded another spectacle within a month, just ahead of the th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution.Laika, another stray from the streets of Moscow, fulfilled his wishes when she became the first dog to orbit the Earth, in Sputnik . The craft weighed more than half a tonne and the new padded and windowless space dog compartment had air-con.It was also equipped with a feeding system, and a vacuum cup to remove waste.But there was a problem — the technology did not exist to get safely back to Earth.On November  Laika blasted off from the new Baikonur Cosmodrome. Readings of her pulse and breathing suggest she was frightened by the initial acceleration but relaxed when the capsule reached orbit and she became weightless.But within minutes of the spacecraft reaching orbit, the living compartment began to overheat and cooling fans could not cope.With temperatures reaching more than C, it is now certain that Laika died after about two hours. At the time, no one in Russia or where, except those working on the mission, knew the truth.Soviet media declared that Laika was alive and well. Five months later her remains were destroyed when the satellite burned up as it re-entered the Earth’s atmosphere.In the US, animal rights groups protested about the flight and cruelty of the one-way mission.But across the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, Laika was celebrated as a heroine.She was the first of the space dogs to be commemorated in books, on stamps and postcards.You could buy Laika-branded cigarettes and matches and her image was printed on ornaments, paperweights, clocks and watches. Although the sub-orbital flights continued, orbital flights were put on hold until Korolev could perfect a means of bringing the animals back alive.Dogs Belka and Strelka launched in August , alongside two rats,  mice and a selection of insects, cultures of microbes and seeds.Sputnik  was the second attempt to send dogs into orbit andthem safely to Earth.The spacecraft was far more sophisticated than Laika’s.As well as TV cameras, it incorporated solar cells for power and a refrigerated cooling system.After  orbits, Korolev gave the command to slow the spacecraft down and drop it out of orbit.Belka and Strelka plummeted to Earth at more than G. At ,ft the parachutes opened. The dogs were unharmed and wagged their tails to greet their masters.The public reaction was overwhelming — here were two of the cutest and happiest dogs, back on Earth after flying in space.The pair were introduced to VIPs and appeared with their handlers on TV as chat show guests. They were superstars with all the mass-produced memorabilia to match.They were portrayed smiling in spacesuits, peering out of rocket portholes or driving side by side in stylised space ships, whizzing around among the stars. There were figurines, animations, books and stories.On May , , America finally managed to get astronaut Alan Shepard off the ground and back to Earth on a -minute sub- orbital flight.The Vienna Conference of  was the first opportunity for Khrushchev to meet US President John F Kennedy.Both leaders were wary. But during dinner, First Lady Jackie Kennedy turned to the subject of space dogs.By now Strelka had given birth to a healthy litter of puppies and Jackie suggested that Khrushchev should send her one.A few weeks later, the White House received an unexpected delivery from the Soviet Embassy — a puppy with a Russian passport.The FBI combed through the fur of the tiny dog, checking it for surveillance bugs. But space puppy Pushinka was allowed to stay.When the Cuban Missile Crisis threatened to kick-off World War Three in October , having Pushinka in the White House may have played a role in helping the leaders step back from the brink.White House Welsh terrier Charlie took a particular shine to the Russian female and in June  the pair became the proud parents of a litter of puppies.The Kennedys decided to give two of the puppies away to American children.It is likely that somewhere in America, descendants of those dogs are alive today. When Yuri Gagarin parachuted to Earth in April , using the technology pioneered by Belka and Strelka, he succeeded them as a new national space hero.But the Russians planned one last canine space effort.On February , , space dogs Ugolek and Veterok had launched into orbit in an adapted Voskhod capsule. The mission took them high above the Earth, through the Van Allen radiation belts.Eventually, after  days, the retrorockets fired and the dogs came back to Earth.Their first steps were shaky but they survived physically unscathed.Ultimately, the dogs helped enable the Soviets to establish space stations and added to Nasa confidence in sending astronauts to the moon. The legacy of the Soviet space dogs lives on in the souvenirs and memorabilia of the early space race.In , a monument to Laika was unveiled in Moscow, and some of the dogs’ space capsules are on display in the city’s Cosmonautics museum.Today’s astronauts living for months on end on the International Space Station, or those training for ato the moon and trip to Mars, still owe their comfort and safety to the pioneering efforts of stray dogs.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: photo greenland locals code find right house contest
story: The image of the wintry scene in Upernavik taken by Weimin Chu has been chosen as the overall winner of the National Geographic Travel Photo Contest.The small, northwestern fishing village is home to about  residents - making it the th largest village in the country.The photo shows a number of small cottages each painted a dferent colour.Speaking of the village, Mr Chu said the dferent-coloured houses was a sort of code for locals trying to find their way home in the heavy snow.The old Inuit dwellings were simple and easy to construct as the weather and seasons changed.“Historically, Greenlandic buildings were painted dferent colours to indicate dferent s,” he explained.“From red storefronts to blue fishermen’s homes  - a useful distinction when the landscape is blanketed in snow.”Mr Chu hiked near the local airport for expansive views of Upernavik.When homes were lit in the evening, he said “the town looked like a Christmas tree at night”.“It felt so harmonious. The whole land was covered by white, cold snow, and the blue tint at dusk made it even cooler,” he told National Geographic.“But the light from the windows, street lights and the family of three made the world warm again.I love the contrast and mood of this scene. I was busy taking continuous pictures at that time, trying to capture the best moment.”The competition drew entries depicting stunning scenes of vibrant cities, fascinating cultures, and natural beauty from across the globe, these photographers are all deserving of the prestigious gong.

title: jeremy hunt c word vicky ford tory mp
story: Despite being a supporter of the Foreign Secretary in the Tory leadership race, she still managed to accidentally call him the C-word live on air.The Chelmsford MP was being interviewed on the Drive show on BBC  Live by presenter Anna Foster in which she praised his economic policies.She said: “This is why we have in Jeremy C***, Hunt…in Jeremy Hunt a leader who will deliver a strong economy and strong businesses.”Alluding to her gaffe, Foster said: “Vicky, I’m glad that was you and not me.”Her slip up comes after Victoria Derbyshire also mistakenly called the foreign secretary Jeremy C***”, while chairing a debate about who should be the next prime ministerTurning to the Tory MP for Winchester on her show this morning, she begun: Steve Brine, you say that the man that youre backing Jeremy C***...Taking a moment, she then spluttered: Im so sorry - Jeremy Hunt.Clutching her chest, the -year-old BBC presenter, she explained: Ive never said that before in my le.Its usually men who say that so I really, really want to apologise, Im sorry.The two Vics are far from alone in having dropped the C-bomb while attempting to pronounce the MPs name.BBC newsreader Carrie Grace did it in January when she accidentally swapped the H in his surname for a C.Last year, the BBCs Justin Webb said on Radio : “The paper says that health secretary Jeremy C***... Hunt is understood to favour a cap on social care.”Another BBC radio star, James Naughtie, introduced the then-culture secretary in  by saying: After the news we’ll be talking to Jeremy C***.The -year-old politician has also been given the unflattering moniker by BBC political correspondent Ellie Price and Sky News health and science reporter Thomas Moore.Sky anchor Claudia-Liza Armah also made the same slip-up.Speaking on the Speaking to Chopper’s Brexit Podcast, Mr Hunt said broadcasters shouldHe said: “I’m used to it. I had this when I was at school.“Personally I think people should just grow up and get over the fact that my last name rhymes with a rather unpleasant word.”Mr Hunt is one of a number of Tory politicians jockeying to succeed Theresa May as Conservative leader and Prime Minister.He finished second to Boris Johnson in the first round of votes among Tory MPs, who won nearly twice as many votes as the Foreign Secretary.Andrea Leadsom, Esther McVey and Mark Harper were all knocked out after failing to reach the required threshold of  votes to proceed further.Sajid Javid, Matt Hancock and Rory Stewart scraped over the line - but now face a tough fight to keep themselves in the race.

title: theresa may casts vote jeremy hunt
story: After being asked to show her parliamentary pass to prove who she was, Mrs May voted and left the room – telling reporters it was “none of your business” who she backed.But an MP on Mr Hunt’s campaign said: “We’re confident the PM is backing us.”And a source close to the PM said: “The only person who knows who she voted for is herself and Philip May, but it was between Jeremy Hunt and Matt Hancock.”The PM, wearing a long black coat and leopard print kitten heels, cast her vote along with all  fellow Tory MPs in a secret ballot in a Parliamentary committee room yesterday morning.Mr Hunt’s team were also confident they had won the backing of Chancellor Philip Hammond.He refused to reveal who he had backed, telling reporters as he left the room: “I’m not telling you.”The Sun can also reveal the PM invited David Davis - one of her fiercest Brexit critics - in to her No flat for a private one-to-one drink on Wednesday night. Mr Davis said he was not lobbying on behalf of leadership contender Dominic Raab, who he voted for in the first ballot yesterday.Mr Davis was the first minister to quit Mrs May’s Cabinet over Brexit when he walked out over the Chequers deal last July.Mr Davis was initially turned away from voting in yesterday’s Tory leadership contest because he forgot his ID. The party has introduced voter ID in the leadership election for the first time. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc stars join tv licence backlash to scrap free telly oaps
story: At present, all over-s receive a free TV licence, but from next year it will be means-tested and only those households with a member who receives pension credit will be eligible.Former Strictly Come Dancing judge Len Goodman, , slammed the proposal as rotten.He said: “It will impact on the most vulnerable, the most lonely and the poorest. I’m not a politician, I’m just a dance teacher from Dartford, but I think it’s rotten.He added: I feel sorry for older people maybe their families live miles away, some people don’t see anyone for weeks on end.“They’ve got their pension and that’s about it. And to take another £...I don’t know how you decide who is the poorest and who’s the most deserving.“I’m  and % not deserving and there are tens and thousands of people similar to me who could well afford to pay their licence.“But there are hundreds of thousands for whom it would impact on their standard of living. A lot of people don’t even know what the Pension Credit is. They don’t understand it.Dame Esther Rantzen, , said getting rid of the free TV licence fee for over-s would be seriously damaging to those who relied on it for companionship and who will struggle to pay the £. annual fee.She called it an “act of cruelty” that sent a message to the millions affected that “you are a nuisance, a burden, we don’t want you”.Dame Esther, who hosted BBC show That’s Le! from  to , added: “It’s no good saying how much we owe older people on D-Day and then dropping them in it. It’s not respectful and it’s not right.”Royle Family star Ricky Tomlinson marched with pensioners on the BBCs northern headquarters last night in protest against the plans.The actor, , branded politicians a blood shower of hypocrites in a rallying cry to his fellow protesters, telling them of the subsidised grub for MPs and the £ daily attendance fee in the House of Lords.He said: One of the biggest things [elderly people] have got to keep them going is the television.Its a leline to them and we are talking about taking it away andnot taking it away, charging them for having it.I think its an absolute disgrace. And anyone who votes for that should be ashamed of themselves and quit their job as an MP.I dont think the BBC should be funding this at all - I think the Government should be funding this.Theyve got millions and millions of pounds to spend on arms and rockets and things to destroy people, were asking them to look after our pensioners and pay the licence for them, which is only £ a year.BBC presenter Ben Fogle said he was ashamed at how older people were being treated.He has pledged to donate his entire salary from this years series of the BBCs Animal Park programme to subsidise TV licences for pensioners.The former Countryfile presenter said: Im ashamed to say that we as a nation are not looking out for those who fought and risked their lives for us all - they deserve better.TV brings great comfort to millions of older people who live alone and those who are housebound - no doubt helping them to keep informed, entertained and connected to the outside world.I just cant believe this is being taken away from them.The BBC has said the move aims to protect programming while dealing with the extra funding burden sparked by the Government passing the cost of funding free licences onto the BBC as part of an updated charter agreement in .More than three million people aged over  will have to pay for their TV licence when the new scheme comes into effect on June  .Those found to be ineligible for a free licence will have to pay £. a year for a colour television and £ a year for a black and white set.Around half a million people so far have signed a petition opposing the move.Norman Jemison, , a vice president of the National Pensioners Convention said the BBC board could resign and refuse to do the Governments dirty work.A Government spokesman said: Were very disappointed with this decision - weve been clear that we want and expect the BBC to continue this concession.People across the country value television as a way to stay connected, and we want the BBC to look at further ways to support older people.Taxpayers want to see the BBC using its substantial licence fee income in an appropriate way to ensure it delivers for UK audiences, which includes showing restraint on salaries for senior staff.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: royal marines commandos ferry exercise
story: Holidaymakers packed upper decks to watch on the voyage to Plymouth from Roscoff in France.The Royal Navy said: “Commando teams in fast boats reached Brittany Ferries’ Armorique ten miles off the south coast.Then  troops from  Commando made a daring ascent of the nine-deck ferry in notoriously dficult conditions.The marines made the audacious climb by cable ladder to the upper decks of the ferry, all while cutting through the water at around mph.Captain Jack Denniss, of  Assault Squadron, said: “The Royal Marines are one of only a few forces in the UK trained to conduct this sort of operation, so it is vital we do this training regularly, under the most arduous conditions possible.During this sort of boarding, the point of greatest vulnerability can often be the embarkation.In fact, achieving access to a fast-moving vessel is in some cases more dangerous than the enemy protecting it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: outdoor health happiness increased exercise
story: And the benefits of chilling in a park, forest or on the beach are comparable to those achieved through exercise, researchers say.Those who embraced nature for just a couple of hours or more a week were  per cent more likely to feel in good health.They were also  per cent more likely to be satisfied with le than those who never ventured out.Researcher Dr Mat White said: “Two hours a week is hopefully a realistic target for many people, especially given that it can be spread over an entire week to get the benefit.”The findings come from a University of Exeter analysis of data on nearly , people.The benefits became evident only after two hours and ­plateaued between three hours  minutes and five hours.It did not matterit was clocked up in one go or over several shorter trips but being in the garden did not count.Spending time outside is said to lower stress and blood pressure. But the researchers say it is the first time theof time needed to help has been identied.Prof Terry Hartig, who also worked on the study at Uppsala University in Sweden, said doctors should encourage patients to explore nature.He added: “There are many reasons why spending time in nature may be good for health and wellbeing.“This includes getting perspective on le circumstances, reducing stress, and enjoying quality time with friends and family.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: british dishes ranked god worst tier
story: A YouGov survey has ranked classic savoury and sweet British dishes from God Tier for deliciousness to Worst Tier for foods we hate.Yorkshire pudding, Sunday roast, fish ’n’ chips and Victoria sponge came out on top with more than  per cent calling them the best. The Worst Tier was enjoyed by fewer than half of those surveyed.The low rating for Scotch eggs and pork pies left a sour taste too.Andy Bullock tweeted: “Scotch eggs are Low Tier  What is wrong with people.”Feast your eyes on the full list, compiled by Kate Jackson, and seeyou agree.Jam roly-polyHarry Redknapp’s favourite pud was invented in the early th century and was traditionally boiled in a shirt sleeve, giving it the nickname “Dead man’s arm”.Scotch eggsPosh London store Fortnum  Mason claims to have invented scotch eggs, for travellers to eat on their journeys, but there are claims they started in Africa, India and even Yorkshire. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: philip green critics jealous wealth
story: The former BHS owner — now battling to save his Arcadia empire — claims the media is whipping up the public against him.Green, , who denies the allegations against him, told the BBC: “You lot make them all . . . jealous, that’s why.It’s quite basic. These people writing all this s*** couldn’t spell  quid. They all get jealous.“They don’t like someone who can write out a cheque and writes one out — people do not like it.”Green also batted away suggestions that Arcadia — which includes Topshop and Burton — had been on the brink of collapse this week.Administrators were put on standby before a rescue deal was approved by landlords on Wednesday.Green said: “It didn’t come close to collapse. Many more landlords clearly voted yes than no.”He also explained why he was pouring several more hundred million pounds of his family’s money into Arcadia, saying it had stopped “an ugly car crash”.He added: “You don’t want to see all the people out of work when you could have assisted.”And he admitted: “Whether we haven’t changed quickly enough or we had too many shops or whatever — you can’t get it all right.”Arcadia will shut  shops with the loss of , jobs.Rent reductions and restructuring should safeguard the remaining , workers.Green is due in a US court on Wednesday on four assault charges. He denies them.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: macron ultimatum brexit deal
story: The French President wants Brussels chiefs to issue a warning to the next PM that failure to accept the current terms will lead to No Deal on October .He is pushing for a statement slamming the lack of any progress made in Westminster since the last delay was granted in April.The warning shot would also be pessimistic over likelihood of a breakthrough in the next few months given the promises made by Tory leadership candidates.EU diplomats said countries previously softer on Britain, including Germany, are now starting to come round to the French President’s way of thinking.One told The Sun: “Macron’s priority is to get the UK out as soon as possible and get No Deal done with.“France is pushing for strong language telling the Brits this is the final deal and we’re not going to re-evaluate the deal, so accept it or don’t.”Mr Macron’s demand will set up a power struggle with Brussels boss Donald Tusk, who wants to take a much softer line towards Britain.The Council chief, who still holds out hope of a second referendum, would have to deliver the ultimatum personallyit’s agreed by capitals.Senior eurocrats still expect Mr Johnson to U-turn on his pledge to leave on October  with or without a deal and seek more time for negotiations.Top EU sources said the Tory frontrunner will not have enough time to secure further assurances on the hated border fix before our exit date.They said he can get changes to the trade plan emphasising its temporary nature, but reopening the legally binding Withdrawal Agreement is off limits.But Mr Johnson will be held to a higher standard by leaders that Theresa May and will have to prove he has a parliamentary majority before talks proceed.A senior EU source told The Sun: “For certain he will have to violate one of the first rules that he has set, meaning no extension.“I can’t imagine that he simply comes to Europe and says game over, this is it, I’m going for No Deal.“He will have to at least an attempt to say this is the offer and this is it andnot we’re going for No Deal.“The likelihood that Boris will be forced to come and ask for another extension seems rather big.”They also said Mr Johnson could secure a plan for the “dynamic erosion” of the backstop over time. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: chuka umunna joins liberal democrats
story: The move is a humiliating climbdown for the arch-Remainer who has previously said you “can’t trust the Lib Dems”.But he has now thrown his lot in with Sir Vince Cable after his new anti-Brexit Party Change UK split amid bitter in-fighting.Announcing his move last night, Mr Umunna said: “After leaving Labour, I had thought that Britain needed a new party and I believed that was what the millions of politically homeless people in Britain wanted.“I was wrong.”He admitted that he has been a ferocious critic of the Lib Dems.But he said: “Four years on from their time in office, things have changed.”It comes as the struggling splinter party he helped to set up changed its name yet again after being threatened with legal action.In the latest humiliation for Change UK, they announced they will now be known as The Independent Group for Change after Change.org said it would sue their MPs inidually unless they budged.Mr Umunna, the MP for Streatham in South London, used to be a rising star in Labour and ran briefly for leader in .But he quit the party in a furious row over Brexit and the hard left direction Jeremy Corbyn was taking it in.He set up Change UK with fellow anti-Brexit Tory and Labour splitters, but quit earlier this month after they flopped in the Euro elections.In an interview with the Times, when askedhe was prepared for the backlash from his former colleagues, he said: Ive got a pretty thick skin.You dont leave all of the political security of what are the two main partiesyoure out for self-advancement.And Im not sure what more I could do to prove that Im not, not a careerist.Sir Vince, the Lib Dem’s outgoing leader, hailed him as a “formidable, serious political figure” who would be a positive addition to the party.He said: Chuka and I have worked together effectively for many months, campaigning for a Peoples Vote and to Stop Brexit.I know that he will be a great asset to our party not just on Brexit, but in fighting for the liberal and social democratic values that we share.He joins alongside , people across the country just this month, demonstrating clearly that the Liberal Democrats are the biggest, clearest and most formidable force in the liberal centre-ground of British politics today.His decision to join the Lib Dems was also welcomed by current deputy leader Jo Swinson, who is running for leadership of the party.She said: I have worked with Chuka on the Peoples Vote campaign, and I know the passion, intellect, and energy he will bring to our party, and our campaign to stop Brexit.This proves that the Liberal Democrats are the rallying point for those who are opposed to Brexit, want to tackle the climate emergency and want to stand up to the forces of nationalism and populism.There are millions of people, like Chuka, who share those values, and I want them to join our party.However, Labour MP John Mann has called on Umunna to call a by-election after confirming his move.Mr Mann tweeted: Lets see Chuka show some bottle and call a by-Election.Not holding my breath.

title: chancellor urges tory leadership rivals
story: NewsChancellor urges Tory leadership rivals to show financial competencePhilip Hammond said the Tory Party had a "hard-won reputation for being financially responsibleShareByHarriet Line:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsHes written to all those still in the race "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailChancellor Philip Hammond has written to the Tory leadership candidates asking them to pledge to keep national debt falling every year. Philip Hammondaposs letter in full:Dear The Conservative Party has a hard-won reputation for fiscal and economic competence that has been the bedrock of our electoral success over generations. As we enter the campaign to select our next leader, it is vital that we do not throw that away.When we took office in , we inherited the largest deficit in peacetime history, at .% of GDP. Thanks to sound economic policy and the hard work of the British people, our deficit is down to a more manageable level of .%. However, the years of high deficits have taken a toll on our national debt, which rose from around % of GDP before the financial crisis to a peak of over % in -, its highest level in fty years. Thankfully, our debt is now falling sustainably for the first time in a generation. As we look forward, it is vital that we do not undo these achievements by making unfunded commitments that would mean debt rising again leave the economy vulnerable to shocks burden future generations and waste billions on additional interest payments.If we do not commit to getting our debt down after a nine-year run of uninterrupted economic growth, how can we demonstrate a iding line between the fiscal responsibility of our party and the reckless promises of John McDonnell and Jeremy Corbyn I therefore ask you, as a candidate for the leadership of the Conservative Party, to pledge thatyou are the next Prime Minister your government will, at a minimum, have a clear commitment to keeping our national debt falling every year, and to maintain the current limit of the deficit at % of GDP at least through -. As I said at the Spring Statement,we can avoid major economic shocks andwe leave the EU in a smooth and orderly way, an incoming Prime Minister will have genuine choices about how to use the available borrowing capacity implied by these fiscal commitments: increased spending on public services, capital investment in Britain’s future prosperity, cutting taxes or more rapidly reducing the national debt. On the current OBR forecast, these commitments would mean, after allowing for the expected reclassication by the ONS of student debt, around £ billion of headroom available in - £ billion in - £ billion in - and £ billion in -, though a prudent administration would not use all the available borrowing capacity given the potential for forecast revisions.I have written in similar terms to all candidates. I am releasing this letter to the media and will similarly release responses I receive from candidates.I look forward to your response.

title: paul routledge next tory pm
story: NewsopinionPaul Routledge: Next Tory PM will be Southerner that is clueless about the NorthSeedy politicians now vying to succeed Theresa May let the steel industry of Redcar die. Their party closed the pits. They starved the region of investment, pouring money into the wealthy SouthShareCommentsByPaul Routledge:,  JUN NewsopinionForeign Secretary Jeremy Hunt, the filthy-rich assassin of the NHS, pledges to deliver HS and the Northern Powerhouse Rail – the Tory fantasy east-west link – and “turbo-charge” the economy "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe next Tory PM will be a Southerner from a southern seat with a southern mentality. Like the last two. He - and it looks very likely to be Blarney Boris - won’t have the faintest clue what it’s like for millions who live and work in the North. Up ’ere, where Tory party members are as rare as hens’ teeth, he’ll be helped into power by a tiny fraction of the voting population. He won’t care. The working class can kiss his arse – he’s got the foreman’s job at last. Seedy politicians now vying to succeed Mrs May let the steel industry of Redcar die. Their party closed the pits. They starved the region of investment, pouring money into the wealthy South.    They closed Sure Start centres. They sacked teachers, school assistants, police officers and PCSOs. They closed hospital beds and brought in private contractors to slash wages and degrade conditions. Want me to go on  OK. They made council workers redundant and cut services for children, the old and vulnerable. They axed our museums and tourist attractions. They’re robbing a million northern pensioners of their free TV licences. Yet front-runners cynically trumpet their support for the media campaign Power Up The North which was launched this week. Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt, the filthy-rich assassin of the NHS, pledges to deliver HS and the Northern Powerhouse Rail – the Tory fantasy east-west link – and “turbo-charge” the economy .  . London ex-banker Sajid Javid bleats “I hear you!” to northerners, from his ­constituency in leafy ­Worcestershire. Boris Johnson famously accused Liverpool people of “wallowing in victimhood” after the Hillsborough tragedy. He also sucks up to hard-line Loyalists in Northern Ireland, but knows nowt about northern England. The airy-fairy promises of wannabe premiers are worthless, just like their manesto commitment to keep free licences for the over-s. Whichever of these sordid, power-mad Tories gets the keys to No , he won’t be the choice of the people of the North.

But that could be whittled down within hours after Boris Johnsonaposs landslide yesterday left rivals reeling. Despite dodging questions, TV interviews and even parking regulations the frontrunner won the backing of  MPs. That was more than twice the totals of his three nearest rivals put together. There is now pressure on the less prominent candidates who scraped through to pull out of the race. But Boris Johnson isnapost home and dry - he faces fresh frustration after refusing to confirm heaposll face TV debates. Here are  fast facts you need this Friday morning. . Matt Hancock may pull out of the race today  Matt Hancock is said to be considering pulling out of the Tory leadership contest this morning after he won just  votes in the first round. The Health Secretaryaposs total was less than his rivals Sajid Javid , Michael Goveand Jeremy Hunt . According to the BBC, Mr Hancock had a meeting with Mr Javid yesterday and is now considering dropping out. A Hancock campaign insider told Playbook the “first rule of politics is to know how to count”. Boris Johnsonaposs allies piled on the pressure overnight, urging minnows and vanity candidates to drop out. In a possible sign somethingaposs afoot, Mr Hancockaposs normally effusive campaign team did notour calls this morning.  Boris Johnson -  MPs Jeremy Hunt -  Michael Gove -  Dominic Raab -  Sajid Javid -  Matt Hancock -  Rory Stewart - KNOCKED OUT :Andrea Leadsom -  Mark Harper -  Esther McVey -   Boris Johnson may have won  votes yesterday - but itaposs by no means plain sailing for the frontrunner. He was today compared to Adolf Hitler by a Muslim leader in the Conservative Party. Mohammed Amin blasted the Tory leadership frontrunner for not having the basic morality and integrity to be PM. And the Conservative Muslim Forum chairman vowed to quit the party after  yearsMr Johnson reaches No. The comments are a devastating attack on the favourite to be Prime Minister after he compared veil-wearing Muslim women to letterboxes and bank robbers. Told many Tory MPs say he’s the right man to sort out the country, Mr Amin replied: A lot of Germans thought that Hitler was the right man for them. Told that was a shocking comparison he added: Yes. I’m not saying Boris Johnson wants to send people to the gas chamber. Clearly he doesn’t, he’s a buffoon. But he as far as I’m concerned has insufficient concern about the nature of truth for me to ever be a member of a party that he leads.  Mr Johnsonaposs opponents have ganged up by committing to appear on TV leadership debates on Sunday and Tuesday, where Channel  has said he will be represented by an empty chairhe refuses to take part. Jeremy Hunt - who is leading the race to be the aposnot Borisapos candidate - slammed him this morning saying: This is the th time Iaposve been on the Today programme in the last year and heaposs just done it once. The ticket on the Toyota, left outside the south London home he shares with partner Carrie Symonds, was issued on May  for parking across two pay-and-display bays. The ticket was issued to the green people carrier, which Mr Johnson is regularly seen driving, on May  at .am. The reason for the fine is given on the notice from Kensington and Cha Council as not parked correctly in the markings of the bay.    . Meanwhile, in Brexit... Firms should start preparing for a no-deal Brexit because they cannot afford to put their faith in politicians to to break the current impasse, a business group has warned. The Institute of Directors said companies should use the time until October  to ensure they understand their potential exposure to leaving the EU without a deal and to take sensible precautions. The IoD said its research showed the proportion of its members who had activated contingency plans increased slightly between January and April, from % to %. But more than half of firms had still not engaged in any contingency planning and only % said they would be using the extension period to pick up the pace. It comes as a number of candidates have said they would be willing to take the UK out of the EU without a deal and Labour lost a bid to give power to parliament to avoid no deal.

title: tory leadership rivals face hustings
story: NewsTory leadership rivals face hustings and £k spending cap as Boris races aheadThe Conservative Party have set out the next stages in the contestShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsBoris Johnson is streaks ahead "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe remaining Tory leadership rivals will face hustings and £k spending cap as the race enters its next stage. Boris Johnson topped the ballot of Tory MPs on Thursday, with Jeremy Hunt, Michael Gove, Dominic Raab, Sajid Javid, Matt Hancock and Rory Stewart also securing enough support to remain in the contest. Three candidates - Mark Harper, Andrea Leadsom and Esther McVey - were eliminated from the race, leaving seven MPs still in the running. Mr Johnsonaposs clear victory,  votes ahead of nearest rival Jeremy Hunt, suggests he will be one of the final candidates competing for the votes of the Tory members across the country who decide the next prime minister.The seven remaining candidates in the race to replace Theresa May face a series of further challenges after surviving the first round of voting.Further ballots are scheduled for th, th and th June and the remaining candidates will need at least  votes to proceed in the next ballot.    The Conservative Party has said there will be  leadership hustings in every region and nation of the UK. Thee first hustings will take place in Birmingham on Saturday nd June and the final debate will take place in London in the week commencing th July. There will also be an opportunity for the public to question the final two candidates online during the hustings period. Conservative Party members should receive postal ballots between th to th July. While the result of the ballot will be announced in the week commencing nd July.  Here are some of the key dates coming up: - Sunday June  - The candidates left in the race have been invited to take part in a TV debate on Channel  hosted by Krishnan Guru-Murthy. - Monday June  - Second round of hustings in front of Conservative MPs with the remaining candidates. - Tuesday June  - Second ballot. Candidates need to secure  votes to continue in the contest. At pm, Emily Maitlis will host a debate for the remaining contenders on BBC One. - Wednesday June  - Third ballot, where the candidate with the fewest votes is eliminated. - Thursday June  - The fourth and fth ballots will continue until just two candidates remain.  The backbench Conservative  Committee - which is running the leadership contest - says it has provision for further ballots, but this is unlikely. The results will be announced at pm and pm respectively. - Saturday June  - Conservative Campaign Headquarterswill begin the membership hustings process for party members to decide between the final two candidates. The party will aim for the hustings to take place in all  regions of the UK. - Week commencing July  - A new leader will be announced following the ballot of , Conservative members. The Prime Minister will then see the Queen to formally resign and the new leader will be invited to Buckingham Palace to form a government.

story: NewsTwo years after Grenfell and , people are STILL living in fearEXCLUSIVE - The Daily Mirror has launched its “Grenfell, Never Again” campaign calling for a raft of changes to unsafe buildingsShareCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politicsMatthew Young:,  JUN NewsTwo years on tens of thousands of people are still living in unsafe buildings "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIn the wake of the Grenfell fire Theresa May promised everything would be done to prevent another such disaster. The Government would do whatever it takes to “keep people safe,” she said. Tomorrow marks the second anniversary of the fire that cost the lives of  people. Two years on tens of thousands of people are still living in unsafe buildings, families are still waiting to the rehoused and fire service funding has been cut. That is why the Daily Mirror has launched its “Grenfell, Never Again” campaign. We are calling for dangerous cladding to be removed from all buildings, the reversal of cuts to fire authorities, sprinklers to be fitteddeemed advisable, an independent regulator to champion tenants’ rights and for an independent authority to oversee the fire service.    Grenfell United’s Karim Mussilhy told the Mirror: “It’s unbelievable that in modern Britain, two years after Grenfell, people are still living in homes that are not fit and buildings that are not safe.” The Government’s own figures show that there are still  high rise and public buildings still clad in the same aluminium compositematerial used on Grenfell Tower. This includes  residential blocks,  hotels and  student accommodation buildings. A further , buildings, including  high rises, are clad in other potentially combustible buildings such as high pressure laminate.  This includes , buildings like hospitals, care homes, schools and hotels that have flammable exteriors but are not high rises. The Department for Housing, Communities and Local Government says ACM cladding has been removed from  buildings since the fire. Grenfell survivors have warned that a “Grenfell Two” is “in the post” because of the Government’s failure to act. Two years after the fire some former residents are still waiting for a permanent home. Of the  households from Grenfell,  remain in temporary accommodation. Fire safety regulations have not been updated and their call for an independent regulator to protect tenants remains unanswered.  “The problem is that it has become increasingly clear than in most cases, those in power simply aren’t interested in acting on our concerns,” said Grenfell United, which represents survivors, in a briefing published to mark the second anniversary of the tragedy. In the wake of the deadly fire in Lakanal House, south London, in  the coroner wrote to the then Communities Secretary Eric Pickles recommending the government encourage the retrofitting of sprinklers in high-rise flats. Despite the call only  out of  council-run tower blocks above mhave sprinklers and only  of the  new build schools. In the last three years every single fire authority has seen a cut in the amount it receives in central government funding. In -, the government spent £,million on fire services. But in -, it will only spend £million. The cuts range from % in Greater Manchester to % in Warwickshire. In Manchester this has seen the number of its firefighters cut by %.  Remove inflammable cladding from all tower blocks and public buildings. Two years on from the Grenfell Tower fire the same aluminium compositecladding is still on  residential and public buildings .A further , buildings, including  high rises, are clad in other potentially combustible buildings such as high pressure laminate. This includes , buildings like hospitals, care homes, schools and hotels that have flammable exteriors but are not high rises.  Retrofit sprinklers in high rises and schools Grenfell has exposed a number of safety issues in blocks across the country, including non-compliant fire doors and lack of sprinklers in blocks. The Coroner’s report into the deadly  Lakanal House fire recommended sprinklers should be retrofitted into all social housing.Only  out of  council tower blocks above mhave sprinklers and only  of the  new build schools. We urgently need all blocks to be made safe, including fitting or upgrading fire safety doors. The Mirror believes sprinklers should be retrofitted when deemed necessary by a risk assessment.  Ensure tenants are given a real voice Grenfell tenants say their concerns about the cheap materials used in the refurbishment were ignored by Kensington and Cha council.We need a new, independent housing regulator with real powers to protect tenants and put people before profits.The Freedom of Information Act should be extended to include tenants’ management organisationsand housing associations. Tenants’ right should be strengthened and democratically-elected groups should be given a direct say on the running and upkeep of their buildings to counter the lobbying by the construction industry.  Reverse the cuts to the firefighter numbers and Fire Safety Officers In -, the government spent £,m on fire services. But in -, it will only spend £m.Every single fire authority has seen the amount it receives in central government funding cut in the last three years. The cuts range from % in Greater Manchester to % in Warwickshire.In Manchester this has seen the number of its firefighters cut by %. The number of fire safety officers has fallen from  in  to  in .Not surprisingly, the number of inspections has fallen from , audits in England in - rot , in - - a fall of %.  New independent national body to oversee standards and best practices in fire service across the country The fragmentation of the fire service means there is no national body to oversee fire and rescue service and fire policy.A new independent national body should be set up with oversight of all fire service professionals, including the FBU, fire chiefs, fire engineers, and fire researchers.This means standards y across authorities and lessons are not being learned. Minimum standards should be set for response times and crewing levels. The number of fire safety officers has fallen from  in  to  in . As a result, the number of inspections has fallen from , audits in England in - to , in - - a fall of %. The FBU says there should a new independent authority to oversee the fire service and minimum standards set for crewing and response times. FBU general secretary Matt Wrack said: “After a decade of austerity, the fire and rescue service is hanging by a thread. With slowing response times and massive cuts to firefighter jobs, a sprinkler system, where appropriate, could make the crucial dference, saving a building from complete destruction.“ “Warnings from residents of unsafe conditions at Grenfell fell on deaf ears. Grenfell was a tragedy born from years of neglect and a community abandoned by the political establishment.  “We need to end the persistent brutal cuts to the fire and rescue service. One in five firefighter jobs have been slashed, fire stations have been closed and crewing levels have been reduced. Resources have been stretched thin, leaving communities exposed. “Fire safety officers are essential to catching dangerous fire risks early on. Massive cuts to their numbers and creeping interventions from the private sector are leaving risks like those at Grenfell unnoticed.” Campaign group JusticeGrenfell was set up in the chaotic days following the tragedy, and is working to provide justice for the bereaved, survivors, those evacuated and the wider community. Backing the Mirror campaign, group co-ordinator Yvette Williams said: “It’s the second anniversary of the fire at Grenfell Tower. We have got a delay in the inquiry and no recommendations for change have been made - and there are things that should be done urgently to save further loss of le. “The things the Daily Mirror is raising around the removal of cladding, the installation of sprinklers and the need for resources for the fire service are urgent needs and need to be implemented now rather than waiting another one or two years down the line. “This does not just effect the Grenfell community but has an impact across the entire nation.” The Mayor of London, Sadiq Khan , also backed the Mirror’s campaign.He said: “Two years on from the tragic fire at Grenfell Tower, the Government’s lack of action is utterly shameful: the local community feels ignored, there are still people whose homes were destroyed living in emergency and temporary accommodation, and building regulations are still unfit for purpose. This advice was updated in December .”  Our petition demands  Remove inflammable cladding from all tower blocks and public buildings.
